thread.title: Daniel Murphy has no clue how sudden power emerged
thread.title_full: Daniel Murphy has no clue how sudden power emerged | New York Post

author: Dan Martin
title: Daniel Murphy has no clue how sudden power emerged
text:
CHICAGO — Forget the Carlos Beltran similarities, David Wright has a different postseason comparison for Daniel Murphy after the second baseman homered again Tuesday night.
“It’s ridiculous,” Wright said after Murphy’s latest homer helped put the Mets a win away from the World Series in a 5-2 win over the Cubs at Wrigley Field. “We were talking in the dugout and being here in Chicago, he should have given the shoulder shrug to [Michael] Jordan after that last one.”
OK, so maybe it’s premature to put Murphy in Jordan’s league before the Mets even finish off the Cubs, but you can understand the hyperbole.
The second baseman went deep again with one out in the third to give the Mets the lead and also hustled home from third on Lucas Duda’s groundout to first in the seventh, when Anthony Rizzo’s throw to the plate was slightly late and off line.
It was the kind of play Murphy had been known for more than his power — until lately.
Now with homers in five straight playoff games, Murphy’s postseason legacy continues to grow as he heads into free agency.
It has left Murphy speechless.
Your browser does not support iframes. “I don’t know,” Murphy said of why he has been so good. “I wish I could explain it. I would have done it like six years ago. I can’t explain it. I can only thank [hitting coaches] Kevin Long and Pat Roessler for the work that they’ve put in with not only myself, but with all the guys hitting. I wish I could explain it. I can’t.”
Some others tried.
“From my perspective, it pretty much doesn’t matter who is pitching right now,” Cubs manager Joe Maddon said. “Obviously, if you look at the line of pitchers that he’s hit home runs against, he’s just in one of those moments.”
And fortunately for the Mets, that moment has stretched for the better part of two postseason series.
“It’s fun to watch,” Wright said. “Being a hitter, I understand how difficult it is to do what he’s doing, to continue this hot streak for 10 days or whatever it’s been. I mean, it’s impressive doing it off these pitchers.”
Even Mets manager Terry Collins, who has been in the sport virtually his entire adult life, couldn’t come up with a similar success story.
“I’ve watched a lot of baseball over the years [and] I don’t think I’ve seen anybody put on this kind of a show on this stage like he has so far,” Collins said. “I mean, even the guys in the dugout, they’re baseball guys too, and they’re saying the same thing.”
And from a player never known for his power, it’s all the more stunning.
“[The] question is: ‘Who is this guy?’ ” Collins said. “I mean, he’s been unbelievable. So hopefully he just keeps it up for certainly a few more games.”
  chicago cubs ,  daniel murphy ,  david wright ,  joe maddon ,  kevin long ,  mlb playoffs ,  new york mets ,  nlcs ,  terry collins
